key_points: The article reflects on Colin Powell's impact as a symbol of Black excellence and the complexities of his legacy.
Powell is praised for rising to the highest ranks of the military and serving as a model of success for Black Americans.
The author acknowledges Powell's controversial role in the Iraq War, specifically his 2003 UN speech falsely claiming Iraq had weapons of mass destruction.
Powell's credibility as a Black man arguably helped sell the war to both American and international audiences.
The piece critiques the concept of Black excellence that aligns with or supports oppressive systems, including American imperialism.
The article discusses other Black leaders, such as Barack Obama and Condoleezza Rice, and their part in maintaining these systems.
It also touches on the idea of double-consciousness described by W.E.B. Du Bois, to explain the inner conflict faced by Black Americans.
Critiques how Black excellence within white-dominated structures can sometimes lead to complicity in systemic violence.
Mentions other figures, such as Rep. Barbara Lee, who have taken stands that align more closely with fighting oppression.
The article encourages a reevaluation of how Black individuals navigate and resist systemic racism and oppression while striving for excellence.
